physdesc.extent: 2 contact sheets and film negatives housed in one folder.

bioghist.head: Biographical note
bioghist.p: B. Hellmich was a photographer whose studio was located at 176 Park Row in Manhattan.

bioghist.head: Historical note
bioghist.p: Cranford Co. was founded by Walter V. Cranford (1861-1935), a civil engineer. The firm was located at 190 Montague Street in the Brooklyn Heights neighborhood and it was responsible for building some of the subway tunnels in New York City. In 1916, the firm was working on portions of Route No. 12, Eastern Parkway, Brooklyn Subway (now the Eastern Parkway Line of the New York City subway), a dual project that was awarded to the Cranford Co. and to the Interborough Rapid Transit Company. This subway line follows Flatbush Avenue through Brooklyn. Cranford Co. also specialized in pavement projects and Cranford served as president of the Independent Asphalt Association in 1908.

list.head: Sources:
list.item: Municipal Engineering, Vol. XXXIV, January - June, 1908.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Roger Imperial photograph collection of buildings on or near Flatbush Avenue in Prospect Heights and Park Slope consists of two contact sheets of modern copies of photographs that belonged to Roger Imperial, as well as modern black-and-white film negatives of the same images that are on the contact sheets. The original photographs were taken by B. Hellmich from July 1914 to November 1915 for the Cranford Construction Company. The images show exterior and interior views of buildings on or or near Flatbush Avenue where it runs through the neighborhoods of Prospect Heights and Park Slope. The modern copies were made by Everett Ortner. An index identifying the location and date of each image on the contact sheets is also included.
